title: How to buy the best home insurance
text:
It’s autumn. That delightful season of mellow fruitfulness that also promises nights dark enough to hide thieves and weather that could irreparably damage most of your home (flooding thanks to a frozen pipe – we’re looking at you).

So what do you do when you’ve already got one eye on the thermostat and another one the latest reports suggesting burglaries are particularly problematic for residents on these fair shores?

Here’s our timely guide.

We’ll tell you what’s true. You can form your own view. From 15p €0.18 $0.18 USD 0.27 a day, more exclusives, analysis and extras.

Why do I need home insurance?

Essentially, home insurance will cover the cost of sorting out your home and the things in it if something goes wrong.

‘Something’ could be anything from vandalism to a flood and everything in between, which means there are two types of home insurance – buildings cover for the property itself and its permanent fixtures and fittings, and contents cover for everything you put in your home. You can buy standalone policies or a single combined policy.

MoneySuperMarket data shows that the average cost of a combined home insurance policy in July 2019 was around £145.

Home insurance may not be compulsory in the same way as car cover, but if you have a mortgage your lender will almost always demand that you have adequate cover in place to cover most eventualities, including landlords with buy-to-let borrowing.

Home insurance for tenants and students

As a tenant, the responsibility to fix the building if it becomes damaged stops with your landlord, the same could sometimes be true if you own property on a leasehold basis like a flat.

But the contents of your home will only ever be your problem so its worth getting proper cover for your stuff.

The average annual cost of contents insurance for tenants is around £59, rising to just over £63 for a typical student.

Home insurance for small or large properties

The cost of home insurance for buildings and contents insurance will be influenced by your location, risk – like flooding or chances of being burgled, and of course the value of your home and contents.

It means that while a combined insurance policy for a bungalow comes in at an average of £125, rising to £143 for a house, a typical bedsit might set you back £350 in annual cover, MoneySuperMarket warns.

How to choose a home insurance policy

“First, make sure you know the value of what you are insuring - check the amount of overall cover for your buildings and contents,” says Brian Brown, head of insight for Defaqto.

“This should be high enough to cover the cost of totally rebuilding your home and replacing all your contents if they were destroyed in say a fire. If you don’t know how much to insure your buildings for the valuation for a recent mortgage should tell you, or you can use the rebuilding costs calculator provided by the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS).

“Many insurers now provide very high fixed sums insured (typically £500,000 for buildings and £50,000 for contents). For most homes this removes the need to estimate the amount you want to insure, but make sure these amounts are enough for your needs. If you insure your home for less than it is worth and you have a big claim the insurer might reduce the amount they pay you in proportion to the amount you are underinsured.”

Check individual limits for things like high risk items (TVs, jewellery, etc.) and make sure the policy will cover you properly for all your belongings.

Consider whether you want cover for accidental damage – this will cost more, but can be worth it in the long run, especially for home contents like TVs, carpets, furniture and the like. And think about insuring valuables you regularly take out of your home, like jewellery and tech.

Bear in mind that some home policies will cover mobile phones for accidental damage or theft, and cover can be much better than offered by some mobile phone policies.

“Look for policies which give you extra add-ons such as home emergency cover, and annual travel insurance,” Brown adds.

“Sometimes these add-ons are included at no extra cost. If you buy one of these policies make sure you know how to use the home emergency service. If it includes annual travel insurance make sure you check to see who is covered.

Where should I buy home insurance?

As with any insurance policy, the right policy, provider and price will be based on your unique circumstances, but researchers like Defaqto and Fairer Finance rate providers overall based on customer experience as well drilling down to pick out the individual policies they think are worth buying.

For example, Fairer Finance has most recently awarded Ecclesiastical, Nationwide, NFU Mutual, HSBC, Santander, Hiscox, Direct Line, Tesco Bank and LV= their five star rating for customer experience while specific policies from Age UK, M&S, Bank of Scotland, NatWest/RBS, Swinton, Saga and TSB all get five stars.
